The utilization of renewable biomass as a sustainable alternative to fossil fuels has emerged as a prominent research focus in chemical engineering. This work presents a comprehensive review of recent advancements in 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) production through catalytic biomass conversion systems, with particular emphasis on biphasic solvent systems employing heterogeneous catalysts for carbohydrate transformation into 5-HMF. Systematic investigations were conducted using various substrates, including monosaccharides (fructose and glucose), disaccharides (cellobiose, sucrose, lactose, and maltose), and polysaccharides (edible and non-edible categories), with analysis of key process parameters impact on conversion efficiency and 5-HMF yield within biphasic system. Furthermore, the reaction mechanisms for the catalytic conversion of diverse substrates to 5-HMF have been comprehensively summarized. This systematic work provides valuable insights and establishes fundamental references for advancing research in the catalytic transformation of biomass-derived feedstocks into high-value platform compounds. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbohydrates 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural Biphasic solvent system Heterogeneous catalysts Catalytic process Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With global fossil fuel consumption surpassing an annual threshold of 13 billion tons of oil equivalent (representing 82% of primary energy utilization), the imperative of resource depletion stemming from their non-renewable characteristics has reached critical significance [1]. This environmental challenge has prompted researchers toward renewable energy systems and eco-efficient technological solutions. It is receiving increasing attention for the synthesis of novel chemical compounds and sustainable fuel alternatives derived from renewable feedstocks [2,3]. Carbohydrates, constituting one of the most abundant classes of organic compounds, represent promising alternatives to petroleum feedstocks. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) has emerged as an essential platform molecule in biorefinery research owing to its distinctive structural characteristics and versatile application potential, with particular emphasis on polymer synthesis, fine chemical production, and renewable fuel development [4]. The molecular structure of 5-HMF contains three chemically active functional groups, including an aldehyde group, a hydroxyl functional group, and an aromatic furan ring, which can achieve various catalytic transformations under controlled reaction conditions [5,6]. These processes generate high-value derivatives such as 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF), 5-ethoxymethylfurfural (EMF), and levulinic acid (LA), as illustrated in Fig. 1 [7–12]. Traditional methods for 5-HMF synthesis predominantly rely on homogeneous catalytic systems, typically employing Lewis acid catalysts, including hydrochloric acid, sulfuric acid, and aluminum chloride [13,14]. While these homogeneous catalysts possessed exceptional catalytic activity and product selectivity, there were significant limitations in industrial-scale applications due to challenges in catalyst recovery and separation from reaction media, coupled with environmental concerns regarding waste management [15]. As organic molten salts composed entirely of ionic species, ionic liquids exhibit unique solvation properties. Nevertheless, their practical implementation encounters multiple obstacles: technically complex synthesis procedures, incomplete resolution of recyclability issues, elevated production costs, and limited successful cases in industrial-scale manufacturing [16,17]. Recent advancements in heterogeneous catalytic systems have emerged as promising candidates for large-scale 5-HMF production, primarily owing to their inherent advantages in facile catalyst separation and efficient recovery/reusability characteristics. In contrast to homogeneous catalysts, heterogeneous catalysts address the intrinsic challenges of recyclability, lowering energy consumption while aligning more closely with the fundamental tenets of green chemistry [18]. The biphasic system, comprising a RP (reaction phase) and an EP (extraction phase), is schematically illustrated in Fig. 2 . RP, typically consisting of aqueous media or polar solvent-water mixtures, solubilizes substrates and facilitates catalytic reactions. Conversely, the EP, generally composed of diverse organic solvents, enhances product separation efficiency and improves reaction yields. Given the significant solvent-dependent variations observed in 5-HMF production efficiency, systematic investigation of solvent selection becomes imperative [15]. Numerous experimental studies have extensively documented the application of heterogeneous catalysts in biphasic system for carbohydrate dehydration to generate 5-HMF, demonstrating the critical role of phase composition optimization in this catalytic process. In this study, a systematic review of catalytic systems used for carbohydrate conversion was carried out through a comprehensive analysis of the literature over the past four decades. The catalytic roles of RP and EP in modulating 5-HMF yields were systematically investigated while integrating the effects of key process parameters, such as chemical modifiers, thermal conditions, and reaction time, and the functional properties such as TOF (turnover frequency) and STY (space-time yield) of different types of heterogeneous catalytic systems were also evaluated. Furthermore, the reaction mechanisms for preparing 5-HMF from different substrates were discussed. These explorations will provide valuable insights and important references for advancing research on the catalytic transformation of biomass feedstocks into high-value platform compounds. 2 Catalytic synthesis of 5-HMF from monosaccharide in the biphasic system 2.1 Fructose Mechanism of fructose conversion: Fructose, a naturally abundant monosaccharide, has emerged as a promising substrate for efficient and sustainable biomass conversion due to its unique physicochemical properties, such as high reactivity and energy density, abundant and sustainable feedstock, and compatibility with catalytic systems [19,20]. The chemical essence of fructose dehydration to produce 5-HMF involves three consecutive protonation steps and the accompanying removal of three molecules of H2O [21]. Depending on whether cyclic intermediates are formed during the reaction, the reaction mechanism can be divided into two main types of pathways: the acyclic intermediate pathway and the cyclic intermediate pathway. As shown in Fig. 3 a, fructose undergoes a first dehydration in the acyclic intermediate pathway to produce the stabilizing intermediate 1,2-enediol, followed by the removal of the second molecule of water to produce 3-deoxyhexosulose. The cyclic intermediate pathway is now more widely accepted. In the cyclic intermediate pathway for the dehydration of fructose to produce 5-HMF, the hydroxyl group at the C2 site of the fructose molecule first undergoes a protonation reaction to form the relatively stable fructofuranosyl carbocation, which is shown in Fig. 3 b. The specific cases of the two pathways are discussed below. Acyclic intermediate pathway: Moreau et al. [22] detected the presence of glucose and mannose during the reaction of fructose degradation, so they concluded that the degradation of fructose starts from an open-chain structure and completes cyclisation at the end. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the intermediate 1,2-enediol produced by this dehydration mechanism is also an intermediate produced by glucose isomerization and the concentration of acyclic fructose is relatively higher in aqueous solution compared to that of acyclic glucose, and therefore this 5-HMF produced by fructose in the pathway is also more abundant [23,24]. Cyclic intermediate pathway: Dharmapriya et al. [25] synthesized a series of hydrogel-based heterogeneous catalysts based on PEGDA (Polyethylene glycol diacrylate), named PEGDA-3SMP-M (M = metal). Comparative catalytic performance experiments showed that PEGDA-3SMP-H had the strongest catalytic activity. In this catalyst system, PEGDA acts as the carrier backbone, while the grafted -SO3H (sulphonic acid group) is capable of dissociating and releasing H+ into the reaction medium to perform Brønsted acid catalysis. Fig. 4 b illustrates the reaction pathway of PEGDA-3SMP-H catalyzed fructose dehydration. It was shown that the protonated oxygen atom (-O+H2, formed from -SO3H protonated substrate or ambient water) in the sulphonic acid moiety follows an E1-elimination mechanism that catalyzes the dehydration process in three steps: two of them involve 1,2-elimination, and the other step is 1,4-elimination. Composition of biphasic solvent systems: The conversion process of 5-HMF from fructose, as systematically outlined in Table 1 , reveals that aqueous solutions are preferentially selected as the RP based on their superior polarity characteristics and exceptional solvation capacity for fructose substrates. Regarding EP selection, non-polar organic solvents demonstrate optimal performance, with MIBK (methyl isobutyl ketone) emerging as the typical candidate owing to its immiscibility with aqueous systems. MIBK has the ability to regulate the equilibrium of rate-limiting steps, inhibit acyclic reaction sequences, and prevents catalyst deactivation [26]. This solvent system further exhibits superior physical and chemical properties, including high distribution coefficient specifically favoring 5-HMF transfer while maintaining minimal solubility for common byproducts, thereby achieving enhanced selectivity during the recovery process. EP and RP can be composed of multiple solvents, for example, Shao et al. [27] introduced DMSO (Dimethyl sulfoxide) and SBA (Sec-butyl alcohol) into the aqueous and MIBK, resulting in a multi-component biphasic system. Gupta et al. [28] noted that DMSO can interact with fructose molecules, specifically, DMSO can facilitate the release of three H2O molecules from fructose molecules in the effect of Gibbs free energy. In the experimental investigation of reaction modifiers, inorganic salts (predominantly NaCl, the most representative modifier) demonstrated significant salting-out effects. However, NaCl is not the sole effective modifier, as evidenced by Wrigstedt et al. [29] who achieved complete substrate utilization (100% conversion) by incorporating KBr (Potassium bromide) in aqueous media. Comparison of catalytic system performance: Table 1 systematically records the TOF and STY. TOF is a measure of catalyst activity that strips away the influence of the total amount of catalyst and is able to focus on the efficiency of the active sites, thus providing a true reflection of the catalyst activity [30,31]. Table 1 showed that the MIL-101-SO3H (MIL, Materials Institute Lavoisier) series of catalysts designed by Aljammal et al. [32] has the highest TOF (11.54 min−1). This may be related to the fact that the system used microwave assistance to greatly reduce the reaction time (5 min) and increase the conversion of fructose (∼100%). The cation exchange resin Lewatit SPC-108 synthesized by Mercadier et al. [33] showed excellent conversion performance in a range of EP, with TOF values ranging from 1.15 to 4.10 min−1, which may be attributed to the small equivalent H+ concentration given by the ion exchanger. STY is commonly used as a measure of the combined production capacity of a reaction system in the spatial and temporal dimensions and is a process parameter used to optimize the design of industrial reactors [31]. We have calculated the STY of fructose under optimized conditions with values distributed between 10−8 to 10−5 mol·cm−3·min−1 and visualized the data (Fig. S1). Overall, high substrate concentration, short reaction time, high 5-HMF yield and small reactor volume are prerequisites for achieving high STY. The catalytic performance of resin-based catalysts: Resin catalysts have gained significant attention in heterogeneous catalysis due to their unique structural advantages as polymeric materials with fixed active sites. These functional polymers possess exceptional physical and chemical properties, including high specific surface area, superior mechanical robustness, remarkable chemical stability, and facile separation from reaction media [34]. The application of ion-exchange resins in carbohydrate conversion was demonstrated in the pioneering work by Mercadier et al. [33], the Lewatit SPC-108 (Sulfonic acid-functionalized polystyrene resin) is used as an acid heterogeneous catalyst for D-fructose dehydration to 5-HMF under different reaction conditions. Lewatit SPC-108 is a macroporous strong acid resins with acid sites provided by -SO3H (sulphonic acid groups). The larger pore size facilitates easier access of the saccharide molecules to these acid sites, thus increasing the yield of 5-HMF. Nafion (501)-H was not selected due to its low ion exchange capacity. This study highlights the need for strong acid sites: weak acid resins such as Duolite CC 3 or Amberlite IRC 50 are unable to catalyze the generation of 5-HMF under the same conditions. Eight organic solvents, including butyronitrile, diethyl ketone, heptane, 2-nitropropane, benzonitrile, 2,2′-dichloroethylether, isopar E, and isopar G were screened as EP for the reaction system containing 22.2 wt% fructose. The fructose conversion and 5-HMF yield were systematically evaluated at a solvent ratio of 1: 9 (v: v). The experimental results showed that 2,2′-dichloroethylether exhibited superior performance in 5-HMF production with a TOF value of 3.77 min−1. Under optimized reaction conditions (84 °C, 300 min), the maximum 5-HMF yield reached 42% when employing 2,2′-dichloroethylether as the EP, providing a theoretical basis for subsequent biomass conversion research. Subsequently, Rigal et al. [35] used this functionalized resin in a biphasic H2O/MIBK system that was maintained at 80 °C under continuous stirring. The system achieved a 5-HMF yield of 44% at 840 min by systematically optimizing the reaction parameters. It is noteworthy that significant progress was made by Roman-Leshkov et al. [36] in 2006 by introducing PVP (polyvinylpyrrolidone) as the additive to the aqueous phase along with DMSO. They utilized ion exchange resins as catalysts and extended the reaction time at high temperatures (180 °C), resulting in an excellent conversion efficiency (89%). In a comparative study of the Amberlyst series of ion exchange resins, Ordomsky et al. [37] used Amberlyst-15 which demonstrated moderate fructose conversion efficiency (∼45%) under specific reaction conditions. According to pyridine infrared (Py-IR) acid quantitative analysis, no Lewis acid sites were detected in Amberlyst-15, so Amberlyst-15 should have the highest Brønsted contribution. Subsequently, Liu et al. [38] performed an optimization using enhanced Amberlyst-36 resin, which significantly improved the catalytic performance by adjusting the parameter system to a reaction temperature of 85 °C and changing the solvent ratio (H2O/MIBK = 1: 1). Liu et al. [38] attained remarkable conversion efficiency of 97% fructose conversion with 87.2% 5-HMF yield within a shortened 50 min reaction duration. The study of the relationship between Amberlyst-36 particle size and 5-HMF yield showed that the increase in pore size led to an increase in internal diffusion resistance, which reduced the 5-HMF yield, and that the most suitable catalyst particle size was in the range of 250 ∼ 450 μm. The STY achieved by Mercadier et al. [33] was 1 to 2 orders of magnitude higher than that of Rigal et al. [35]. This is mainly due to the fact that the former fulfils both the conditions of high substrate concentration and short reaction time. In general, resin-based catalysts use sulfonic acid groups (-SO3H) as Brønsted acid sites, and the H+ they provide promotes the protonation of fructose ring ether oxygen, causing it to open the ring and form a straight-chain ketone fructose. The catalytic performance of metal oxide-based catalysts: As heterogeneous catalysts, metal oxides showed good catalytic activity in biphasic systems, where MIBK is predominantly employed as EP to establish the phase-separated catalytic environment. McNeff et al. [39] reported the utilization of spherical porous TiO2 catalysts for fructose dehydration in an H2O/n-BuOH (n-butanol) biphasic system, achieving an 18% yield under optimized conditions (200 °C, 5 min). The researchers found that generally lower yields were observed when n-BuOH was used as a solvent, and after comparative experiments with short-chain alcohols, MIBK, MIBK-n-BuOH, and 4M2P (4-methyl-2-pentanol) as solvents, concluded that alcohols may be competing for the active catalytic site and thereby reducing catalyst activity. The catalytic performance was notably influenced by solvent selection, where MIBK demonstrated superior performance as EP. This observation was further confirmed by Ordomsky et al. [37] in their investigation of Nb2O5-catalyzed fructose dehydration within H2O/MIBK system. Their results showed that the use of MIBK effectively reduced humin formation, increasing the selectivity of 5-HMF from 60% to nearly 80%. Meanwhile, Ordomsky et al. [37] compared the activity of a series of metal oxides, with the results being: Nb2O5 > ZrPO4 > Al2O3 > SiO2-Al2O3. They were surprised to find that Lewis acid strength also had a certain effect on fructose conversion. In general, metal oxide-based catalysts rely on metal surface hydroxyl (-OH) groups to act as Brønsted acid sites to promote fructose ring opening and dehydration. The catalytic performance of inorganic salt catalysts: Some of the inorganic salts can be categorized as heterogeneous catalysts due to their special solubility. The FePO4 catalyst reported by Yang et al. [40] can partially dissolve and act as a homogeneous catalyst at high temperatures, whereas it can be easily separated and recovered from RP by precipitation after cooling to room temperature, as it is insoluble at low temperatures. They systematically investigated FePO4-catalyzed fructose dehydration in an H2O (NaCl)/THF biphasic system, achieving remarkable catalytic performance with excellent fructose conversion (nearly 99.9%) and 71.5% 5-HMF yield under optimized conditions (140 °C, 15 min), thereby establishing FePO4 as a highly effective heterogeneous catalyst. It is worth mentioning that this catalyst has good stability and can be recycled for five consecutive times with stable yield. To investigate the catalytic mechanism of FePO4, Yang et al. [40] set up a set of controlled experiments. They used FeCl3 or Na3PO4 as catalysts to catalyze cellulose, respectively, and found very low yields of 5-HMF. This suggests that the coexistence of Fe3+ and PO 4 3 − is essential for obtaining high 5-HMF yields. The catalytic performance of molecular sieve catalysts: Molecular sieves, recognized as a class of heterogeneous catalysts with prominent catalytic performance in carbohydrate conversion processes, have been extensively documented in researches to operate within biphasic systems formed through aqueous phase configurations with MIBK and THF [41]. In a pioneering study by Moreau et al. [42], systematic investigations were conducted under optimized conditions (H2O/MIBK = 1: 5 v: v, 165 °C, 60 min reaction duration) to evaluate four H-type molecular sieve catalysts: H-beta, H-ZSM5, H-Y faujasite and H-mordenite. The experimental data revealed that H-mordenite demonstrated superior catalytic performance, achieving a remarkable 5-HMF yield of 69.16%, significantly better than its counterparts. Changes in pore structure and acid site distribution fundamentally affect the stability of the transition state during fructose dehydration: the two-dimensional structure of H-mordenite is a large channel, which allows fructose to enter the catalytic site, and 5-HMF to diffuse rapidly once it is formed, thus preventing it from polymerizing to become a humin; the channel of H-ZSM-5 is relatively narrow resulting in the catalytic reaction being on the outer surface of the catalyst; H-Y faujasite and H-beta have a large cavity structure and 5-HMF is prone to secondary reactions and thus possess lower selectivity. Subsequent research by Ordomsky et al. [43] further confirmed these findings through comprehensive catalyst screening using MIBK as EP. They determined a catalytic efficiency class by comparing 5-HMF yields: H-MOR (Mordenite) (53%) > H-ZSM-5 (46.8%) > H-BEA (Beta) (32%) > amorphous aluminosilicate (16%). The increase in 5-HMF yield can be attributed to the interaction of MIBK with the zeolite pores. Due to the highest strength of acid sites in H-MOR, MIBK interacts more strongly with the strongly acid sites in H-MOR, resulting in longer solvent retention in the zeolite pores, which dilutes 5-HMF and fructose in the pores and prevents polymerization reactions from occurring. In general, the fructose catalysis process mainly relies on H-type molecular sieve catalysts to provide sufficient Brønsted acids to promote the gradual dehydration of fructose. The catalytic performance of the remaining few catalysts: In addition to the catalytic systems mentioned above, several heterogeneous catalysts have demonstrated considerable potential in facilitating fructose dehydration processes, and deserve further attention from the academic community. Notable research was reported by Cao et al. [44] through the development of a cost-effective and facile synthesis protocol for aluminum-exchanged montmorillonite catalysts, wherein the Al-mont-10 variant exhibited superior performance in fructose-to-5-HMF conversion. Al-mont-10 is a Brønsted/Lewis dual acid site heterogeneous catalysts with Lewis acid as the main body (Brønsted/Lewis = 0.016). The results of the NH3-TPD test showed that Lewis/Brønsted acid were moderately acid and weakly acid, respectively. Specifically, Al3+ loaded in montmorillonite acts as a Lewis acid site and the partially hydrolyzed Al-OH moiety acts as a Brønsted acid site, both of which play important roles in fructose dehydration. Under optimized reaction conditions employing the H2O (NaCl)/THF solvent system at 180 °C for 150 min, a high yield (98.5%) was achieved, highlighting its exceptional catalytic efficiency. Parallel investigations by Fan et al. [45] revealed the catalytic capacity of heteropolyacid salt-based materials Ag3PW12O40, demonstrating their dual function as heterogeneous catalysts for Brønsted/Lewis bis-acid sites in 5-HMF synthesis. These hybrid catalysts enabled 77.7% 5-HMF yield with 93.8% selectivity from fructose feedstock at 120 °C within a short reaction duration of 60 min while maintaining operational stability under high substrate concentrations and exhibiting excellent recyclability through 6 times catalytic cycles without significant activity loss (∼6% reduction in 5-HMF yield). Of particular significance, Crisci et al. [46] synthesized highly ordered hexagonal silicate particles TESAS-SBA-15 (TESAS = 3-((3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl)thio)propane-1-sulfonic acid) by using the co-condensation method. The -SO3H group plays the role of the Brønsted acid site and is mainly distributed on the inner surface of the SBA-15 pore. Crisci et al. [46] innovatively used the mixture of MIBK-2-BuOH (7: 3 v: v) with TESAS-SBA-15 as catalyst for the dehydration of fructose. This optimized condition improved the catalytic efficiency and significantly increased the yield to 59.64%, thus providing a valuable reference for carbohydrate conversion processes in heterogeneous catalytic systems. Summary and additions: In general, the dehydration pathway of fructose can be divided into the acyclic intermediate pathway and the cyclic intermediate pathway. Brønsted acids play a major catalytic role, promoting the completion of three-step dehydration of fructose, reconstructing the furan ring, and generating 5-HMF containing a conjugated ketone structure. Although monophasic solvent systems remain prevalent in fructose dehydration processes, biphasic system continues to serve as a widely adopted reaction platform in this transformation [47]. As seen in Table 1, the choice of solvents for EP goes beyond the traditional use of MIBK and other organic solvents, including THF, n-BuOH, MeCN (Acetonitrile), GVL (γ-valerolactone), GBL (γ-butyrolactone) and mixtures of MIBK and 2-BuOH have shown similar suitability for this process. The utilization of heterogeneous catalysts and biphasic system represents a promising strategy for the conversion of fructose to 5-HMF. The catalysts mentioned above, including Lewatit SPC-108 and Amberlyst-15, demonstrate exceptional performance as heterogeneous catalysts in carbohydrate conversion for 5-HMF production. Their heterogeneous nature enables effective operation in biphasic systems while facilitating straightforward separation from the reaction mixture through filtration or centrifugation post-reaction. This inherent characteristic significantly minimizes post-reaction purification requirements and permits potential catalyst reuse, thereby enhancing process sustainability through cost reduction and environmental impact mitigation. 2.2 Glucose Mechanisms of glucose conversion: Glucose, the most abundant monosaccharide in nature, serves as a cornerstone substrate for biomass conversion due to its widespread availability, versatile reactivity, and compatibility with biological and chemical processes. Numerous studies have shown that a conventional reaction pathway exists for the conversion of glucose to 5-HMF with fructose as an intermediate product, and the reaction mechanism is shown in Fig. 5 : Glucose is first isomerized to fructose in the presence of Lewis acid and then stripped of three water molecules to become 5-HMF in the presence of Brønsted acid; Unwanted by-products such as humin may result from cross-polymerization of glucose, fructose, and 5-HMF, respectively, while LA and FA (Formic acid) are 5-HMF rehydration. However, there are also unconventional reaction pathways that do not need to undergo isomerization. The mechanism of glucose conversion depends on the specific properties of the heterogeneous catalysts, so we explore the specific role of the heterogeneous catalysts for the respective mechanisms according to the conventional pathway, which uses fructose as an intermediate, and the unconventional pathway, which does not produce fructose. Glucose isomerization pathway: Glucose isomerization goes through three main stages: 1) ring-opening of glucopyranose to the acyclic form of glucose; 2) enol-ketone isomerization; 3) ring-closing of acyclic fructose to fructofuranose [48]. Zhao et al. [49] synthesized 0.5Al-HfOx-500, a hafnium-aluminum bimetallic oxide catalyst, in which the metal species and the Hf-OH and Al-OH groups on its surface act as Lewis acid centers and Brønsted acid centers, respectively. The synergistic action of aluminum and hafnium species can facilitate the isomerization process of glucose. It is worth mentioning that the five-membered chelate structure formed by O2 and O1 with the Hf active center enables the transfer of H+ from C2 to C1, thus completing the transformation of aldose ketose isomerization, and the key steps of H+ transfer are shown in Fig. 6 a. Nahavandi et al. [50] synthesized a sulfonated carbon-based solid acid catalyst, where the Brønsted basicity provided by ketone and carbonyl type oxygen functional groups drives the base-catalyzed isomerization of glucose to fructose. The important intermediate enediol - the bridge connecting the two conformational isomer transformations of glucose and fructose is formed by the transfer of a proton on acyclic glucose to glucose and sulphonic acid, and the key steps are shown in Fig. 6 b. Glucose non-isomerization pathway: Noma et al. [51] discovered a new dehydration pathway in which glucose undergoes a three-steps dehydration directly at the Lewis acid site to produce the 3-deoxyglucosone intermediate, with the key steps shown in Fig. 6 c. This may be due to the fact that the phosphate group binds to the OH group on the surface of TiO2 through esterification, consuming the strongest Brønsted acid site of phosphoric acid, and the remaining two weak acid sites are not able to catalyze the reaction efficiently at the reaction temperature. Zhao et al. [52] explored a reaction pathway using the acid-base bifunctional heteropolyacid-based ionic hybrids catalyst [MimAM]H2PW12O40 with 1,2-enediol and anhydrosugars as important intermediates. The 1,2-enediol is stabilized by hydrogen bonds formed between the heteropolyanion and the hydroxyl group, and then dehydrated by the synergistic action of the dual acids to form 5-HMF, with the reaction pathway shown in Fig. 6 d. These two reactions are essentially the same. Composition of biphasic solvent systems: Table 2 systematically investigates the optimized reaction parameters in biphasic system utilizing glucose as the primary substrate. In the biphasic system, the aqueous phase mainly plays the role of RP, while EP exhibits significant compositional diversity. The most commonly used solvent in experiments remains MIBK, which has been shown to have numerous advantages, followed by THF and a number of less conventional alternatives, including MeCN, ethyl acetate, GVL and toluene [26]. As evidenced by the experimental data presented in Table 2, THF demonstrates exceptional performance as EP in dehydration processes. As a cyclic ether, the oxetane structure of THF improves the ability to extract the resulting 5-HMF and has the advantage of being inexpensive and low energy consumption for the separation of 5-HMF (compared to MeTHF (2-Methyltetrahydrofuran) and dioxane, respectively) [53]. In solvent systems, 1,4-dioxane is a specialized EP demonstrating unique phase-stabilization capabilities, which stabilizes the production of 5-HMF in RP and promotes its preferential partitioning into EP. Atanda et al. [54] successfully synthesized TiO2-ZrO2 solid acid catalysts by sol-gel method and achieved 85.9% yield of 5-HMF using 1,4-dioxane as solvent under 175 °C with 180 min. As can be seen from Table 2, NaCl is still the most frequently used modifier but not the only choice. Garcia-Sancho et al. [55] used CaCl2 as a modifier in dehydration experiments with glucose, which contributed greatly to the improvement of glucose conversions (96%), but due to poor selectivity (54.17%), the 5-HMF yield could only reach 52%. All of the above experimental results show that aqueous solutions are the commonly used RP in biphasic systems, and although there are a variety of solvents that can make up the EP, MIBK is still the predominant one. The catalytic performance of resin-based catalysts: Resin catalysts have been favored for their commerciality and efficient catalytic performance. Significant advances in catalyst recycling technology have been demonstrated in a recent study by Wang et al. [56], who reported a novel polydivinylbenzene-based polymeric material containing water-resistant functional groups (SO2NHSO2C4F9) coordinated to Cr (III), wherein Cr (III) efficiently facilitates glucose to fructose isomerization reactions. The particular hydrophobicity of the sulfonic acid moiety facilitates the reuse of the catalyst, resulting in only a 2% decrease in 5-HMF yield over 12 consecutive cycles of the catalyst. The optimized Cr (III)/PDVB-0.3-SSFBI (PDVB = hydrophobic PDVB support, SSFBI = PhSO2NHSO2C4F9) catalyst exhibits excellent catalytic performance, achieving 95% glucose conversion and 59% 5-HMF yield under optimized reaction conditions (140 °C, 30 min). A systematic study of the (acid + KBr) (aq)-MeCN system was carried out by Wrigstedt et al. [29], who found that MeCN accelerated the conversion of fructose and improved the selectivity and yield of 5-HMF compared to conventional organic solvents (MIBK, THF and 2-BuOH). After extensive comparative experiments, they found that the use of the alkali metal salt CrCl3·6H2O in combination with Amberlyst-38 under microwave radiation conditions was very effective in promoting the catalysis of glucose isomerization. Cr3+ acts as a Lewis acid, forming chelate complexes with glucose, promoting the production of enediol intermediates and accelerating the isomerization of glucose to fructose. GVL has been extensively studied as a renewable solvent for biomass conversion [57,58]. For example, Wrigstedt et al. [29] obtained 74% 5-HMF yield and 98% glucose conversion in 3 min in the (CrCl3·6H2O + Amberlyst-38 + KBr)(aq)-GVL system. It is worth mentioning that Ravasco et al. [59] used a Cr3+-modified cation exchange resin, Amberlyst15 + Cr3+, to convert glucose to 5-HMF using H2O-TEAB (Tetraethyl ammonium bromide)/ethyl acetate as the reaction medium to obtain a high STY (3.02 × 10−6 mol·cm−3·min−1). This may be due to the combined effect of Amberlyst15 + Cr3+ being able to convert more glucose (0.7 g) in a shorter period of time (60 min) and achieving a high yield (70%). RP in biphasic systems using resin-based catalysts is usually the aqueous solution, and EP is selected from THF, GVL, ethyl acetate, and mixtures of MIBK with n-BuOH. In general, resin-based catalysts catalyze the conversion of glucose by relying on externally added metal cations as Lewis acids. The Brønsted acid sites provided by the catalysts themselves are insufficient to promote effective isomerization of glucose. The catalytic performance of metal oxide-based catalysts: Metal oxides, an important type of catalytic materials extensively utilized in heterogeneous catalysis systems, have been systematically studied together with diverse EP. Particularly, MIBK exhibits predominant solvent effects as the most frequently employed EP in biphasic system, while THF, 2-BuOH, and 1,4-dioxane also demonstrate significant solvent-mediated functionalities in specific catalytic processes. Notably, nanostructured titanium dioxide (TiO2) has attracted considerable research attention due to its exceptional catalytic performance in carbohydrate conversion reactions. In a study conducted by Dutta et al. [60], self-assembled spherical TiO2 NPs (TiO2 nanoparticles) catalysts were employed to facilitate the microwave-assisted dehydration of glucose in the biphasic system. Under optimized conditions employing H2O/MIBK = 1: 2 v: v at 130 °C for 5 min, the catalytic system achieved a 5-HMF yield of 25.9%. The mesoporous structure of TiO2 NPs has a large external surface area (326 m2 g−1), which allows glucose molecules to react by binding to Lewis acid sites on its external surface, while the strong acidity (0.4 mmol g−1) facilitates the dehydration of carbohydrates. McNeff et al. [39] reported enhanced catalytic efficiency using identical TiO2 nanocatalysts under modified reaction parameters, where thermal treatment at 180 °C for 2 min in the biphasic system with an elevated H2O/MIBK = 1: 10 v: v resulted in improved 5-HMF production reaching 29%. Nevertheless, a systematic modification of this approach was carried out by Atanda et al. [54] who developed TiO2-ZrO2 binary oxide composites. They employed dioxane as EP and introduced NaCl as the modifier, and the optimized catalytic system exhibited excellent performance in biomass conversion, with an 85.9% yield of 5-HMF. Transition metal oxides, particularly tantalum-based catalysts, have shown exceptional performance in carbohydrate transformations, as demonstrated by Yang et al. [61] innovatively utilized the TA-p (Modified hydrated tantalum oxide) catalysts in the H2O/2-BuOH biphasic system, achieving 70% glucose conversion and 58% 5-HMF yield under optimized reaction parameters (160 °C, 140 min). Jimenez-Morales et al. [62] prepared mesoporous tantalum oxide by acid hydrolysis of tantalum penta-ethoxide in the presence of a nonionic surfactant (Pluronic L-121) and calcination. This heterogeneous catalyst was reacted at 175 °C for 90 min to give a yield of only 23%. Although the catalytic efficiency of this catalyst was not ideal, it was effective in inhibiting the rehydration of 5-HMF to LA. In addition, there is a wide variety of metal oxides, among which Al2O3, Nb2O5, Nb0.2-WO3, and exhibit stable catalytic properties in their respective systems [48,55,63]. In conclusion, in metal oxide systems, aqueous solutions are the most commonly used RP, and there are many choices for EP, including organic solvents such as MIBK, THF, 2-BuOH and 1,4-dioxane. In general, metal oxide-based catalysts exhibit synergistic catalysis through Brønsted/Lewis dual acid sites: metal cations act as Lewis acids to promote glucose isomerization; hydroxyl groups (-OH) present in the solvent or inherent to the metal oxide itself can provide H+ to act as Brønsted acids, promoting fructose dehydration. The catalytic performance of inorganic salt catalysts: Inorganic salts with metal cations can be viewed as a Lewis acid, and since most of them are water-soluble, only a few of the inorganic salts can be used as heterogeneous catalysts on their own, whereas the majority are loaded onto solid materials. Yang et al. [40] systematically investigated the use of FePO4 in glucose dehydration and found that this inorganic salt catalyst remains insoluble at low temperatures, whereas it can be easily recovered by precipitation from RP after cooling to ambient temperature. Glucose conversion efficiency of 97.8% was achieved under optimized reaction conditions (140 °C, 15 min) in the biphasic system of H2O (NaCl)/THF = 1: 3 v: v. However, the yield of the target compound 5-HMF was only 23.1% due to the limited selectivity of glucose conversion to 5-HMF. Degirmenci et al. [64] succeeded in designing a highly efficient loaded catalyst, CrCl2-Im-SBA-15 (Immobilized ionic liquid SBA-15). This catalyst mainly exploits the necessity of the specific coordination environment of Cr (II) species for selective glucose conversion. The results showed that different EP can be used to increase the yield of 5-HMF, with 2-BuOH having the highest extraction capacity for 5-HMF. Degirmenci et al. [64] used MIBK to miscible 2-BuOH (3: 7 v: v) and demonstrated that the highest yield of 5-HMF (35%). In conclusion, current EP for such catalytic systems predominantly utilize MIBK, THF, n-BuOH, and mixture of MIBK and n-BuOH, which have shown optimal 5-HMF yield in their experiments. The catalytic performance of molecular sieve catalysts: The catalytic performance of molecular sieves demonstrates significant advantages in terms of acid tolerance, process efficiency, thermal stability, and facilitated recyclability. The predominant extractants employed in current methodologies remain MIBK and THF. In a noteworthy study conducted by Otomo et al. [41], high aluminum content Beta zeolite (Beta (OF)-Cal500) was used in a biphasic system composed of (H2O-DMSO)/THF, followed by heat treatment at 180 °C for 180 min, resulting in a substrate conversion rate of up to 97% and a product yield of up to 65.96%. The high yield of Beta (OF)-Cal500 compared to its catalyst counterparts is due to the highest number of Brønsted acid sites (0.71 mmol·g−1) and a sufficient number of Lewis acid sites (0.20 mmol·g−1), which are in close proximity to each other at the atomic scale. A large number of Brønsted acid sites is necessary to achieve selective production of 5-HMF, and a sufficient number of Lewis acid sites is essential for the rate-determining isomerization step. Beta (OF)-Cal500 has good stability and is able to maintain high 5-HMF yields (5% yield reduction) over 4 consecutive cycles. A series of hydrotalcite-based composite materials were synthesized by Subsadsana et al. [65] via hydrothermal and dry gel conversion techniques. The ZSM‐5/HT (Hydrotalcite) demonstrated outstanding catalytic performance in the biphasic system with an H2O (NaCl)/THF = 2: 1 v: v, achieving a 5-HMF yield exceeding 65% at 150 °C for 120 min. Interestingly, although both ZSM-5/HT-hydr (Hydrothermal methods) and ZSM-5/HT-dg (Dry gel methods) exhibited desirable catalytic efficiencies, comparative analyses showed that that ZSM-5/HT-hydr exhibited greater structural stability, making it a more promising heterogeneous acid catalyst for the production of 5-HMF from glucose dehydration, with a 25% reduction in 5-HMF yield over 5 cycles. It is worth mentioning that Moreno-Recio et al. [66] designed H-ZSM5 zeolite to convert glucose could reach a TOF value of 17.09 min−1, which may be related to the shorter reaction time (30 min), fewer Lewis acid sites (26 µmol/g), and higher glucose conversion (80%). Overall, molecular sieves as heterogeneous catalysts have the characteristics of easy product separation and recyclability, which enhance the economy of the experiment and have more industrial value. Molecular sieve catalysts obtain Lewis acidity through metal loading, and their unique pore confinement effect stabilizes intermediates and inhibits the formation of by-products. Meanwhile, there are many organic solvents that make up the biphasic system EP, and MIBK and THF are outstanding representatives. In addition to the use of aqueous solutions, RP use a mixture of water and DMSO. The catalytic performance of the remaining few catalysts: HPAs (Heteropolyacids), as a heterogeneous catalyst with excellent properties such as structural clarity, Brønsted acidity, good electron acceptance and release, and high proton mobility, have already attracted much attention in the field of chemical catalysis [67,68]. It has been utilized in experimental investigations conducted by Fan et al. [45] for glucose dehydration processes. This robust material exhibited sustained catalytic activity under demanding reaction conditions, particularly in concentrated glucose solutions containing 30 wt% substrate concentration while delivering exceptional 5-HMF productivity with a remarkable yield of 76.3%. In a study conducted by Wu et al. [69], SP-MS catalysts (SAPO-34 nanocrystalline) were successfully synthesized, which exhibited remarkable catalytic efficacy in a biphasic H2O/MIBK system, achieving that the glucose conversion efficiency was greater than 99%, while the 5-HMF yield reached 81.3%. Wu et al. [69] regulated the Si/Al of SP-MS by varying the amount of TEOS (Tetraethyl orthosilicate) and AC-230 (3-glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane) to achieve the regulation of acid strength and density. Compared to commercial aluminosilicate zeolites and strongly acidic ion exchange resins, SP-MS has a unique surface structure: ultra-high specific surface area (180 m2·g−1), large mesopore volume (0.51 cm3·g−1), medium-strength acidity (capable of preventing the rehydration of 5-HMF, thus reducing the production of LA and FA) and water resistance of SAPO-34 backbone (4 cycles with stable yield). Summary and additions: Glucose is regarded as a model compound in catalytic studies due to its structural characteristics that provide fundamental insights into reaction mechanisms and system behaviors. The conversion of glucose to 5-HMF involves two pathways: isomerization and non-isomerization. In fact, the isomerization pathway is more widely accepted in current research. Within biphasic systems designed for glucose dehydration, aqueous solutions remain the predominant RP, although many studies have demonstrated the effectiveness of improving RP by adding polar solvents. Distinguished examples include systems utilizing H2O-DMSO (9: 1 v: v), H2O-DMSO (3: 1 v: v), H2O-acetone (1: 1.9 v: v) and H2O-TEAB (1: 7 w: w) as the RP, all demonstrating successful glucose conversion outcomes [41,56,59,70]. Although MIBK and THF have always been the main solvents with superior performance in biphasic system, there are still various choices for EP. Prominently, solvent combinations incorporating MIBK with n-BuOH have been documented in specific catalytic systems. This heterogeneous catalytic system for glucose facilitates reaction and separation, effectively addressing critical challenges in biomass conversion while maintaining catalytic efficiency. 3 Catalytic synthesis of 5-HMF from disaccharide in the biphasic system Mechanism of disaccharide conversion: Disaccharides, a class of naturally abundant carbohydrates, are structurally characterized by the covalent linkage of two monosaccharide units through glycosidic bonds, with representative examples including cellobiose, sucrose, lactose, and maltose [71]. The catalytic conversion of disaccharides to 5-HMF presents greater technical challenges than monosaccharide substrates, primarily due to the inherent stability of the glycosidic bonds that necessitates sequential reaction steps. As shown in Fig. 7 , the mechanism of the conversion of disaccharides to 5-HMF usually consists of three successive stages: (1) hydrolytic cleavage of glycosidic bonds to yield constituent monosaccharides (glucose and fructose), (2) subsequent isomerization of glucose to fructose, and (3) final acid-catalyzed dehydration of fructose to generate 5-HMF [72]. These cascading reactions impose stringent requirements on catalyst design, particularly demanding the integration of multiple catalytic functionalities, including hydrolysis, isomerization, and dehydration capabilities within a single catalytic system [73]. Despite these challenges, research efforts have directed at disaccharide conversion with different catalytic and solvent systems, possessing significant potential for advancing the utilization of naturally abundant polysaccharide resources, as disaccharides serve as fundamental structural units in complex carbohydrate polymers. Composition of biphasic solvent systems: Biphasic system, recognized as one of the most promising reaction platforms for carbohydrate conversion, have undergone extensive investigations regarding their compositions [74]. As systematically summarized in Tables 3-5 , aqueous solutions persist as the principal solvent selection for RP in current researches. The superior dissolution capacity of disaccharides in aqueous media is attributed to their molecular structure enabling the formation of hydrogen-bonding networks with aqueous molecules, thereby enhancing their aqueous solubility [75]. Regarding the selection of EP, disaccharides exhibit no distinctive solvent differentiation compared to their monosaccharide counterparts, with MIBK, THF, and GVL maintaining their status as the EP components. It is noteworthy that modifier implementation has become an indispensable strategy in most disaccharide conversion studies, with NaCl emerging as a representative modifier through its salting-out effects. 3.1 Cellobiose Mechanism of cellobiose conversion: Cellobiose, a β-1,4-linked glucose dimer, is an essential model compound in cellulose research due to its structural resemblance to cellulose polymer chains. It makes its catalytic conversion to 5-HMF a critical pathway for advancing sustainable biomass development [76]. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the cellobiose first needs to break the glycosidic bond to produce two glucose molecules, then isomerize to fructose and finally shed three water molecules to produce 5-HMF. Zhu et al. [73] proposed a mechanism for the conversion of cellobiose over a highly active 1Nb-Mont-500 (Niobium-modified montmorillonite) catalyst. As shown in Fig. 8 a, the presence of Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites on the surface of 1Nb-Mont-500 promotes the protonation of oxygen atoms on the cellobiose glycosidic bond, which in turn breaks into two glucose molecules. Isomerization of glucose and dehydration of fructose are similar to that of monosaccharides and will not be discussed here. It is worth noting that the conversion process of cellobiose is limited in terms of spatial dimensions. Wu et al. [69] explained the conversion pathway of cellobiose: SP-MS (SAPO-34 nanocrystalline) possesses an ultra-high external surface area (180 m2·g−1) and large mesopore volume (0.51 cm3·g−1). Researchers proved through spectral analysis that its outer surface has Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, so it can be determined that cellobiose is first hydrolyzed into monosaccharides on the outer surface of SP-MS, and then enters the catalyst pores for the next step of the reaction. The conversion of cellobiose: The comparative analysis indicates that the combination of catalytic efficiency and appropriate solvent selection to effectively extract products and suppress side reactions is a key factor in optimizing the production of 5-HMF disaccharides. Nikolla et al. [77] conducted catalytic conversion in a H2O (NaCl)/THF biphasic system (1: 3 v: v) employing Sn-Beta catalyst at 180 °C, which resulted in a modest substrate conversion rate of 36% with a corresponding 5-HMF yield of 12.96%. Notably, Nikolla et al. [77] added additional HCl to the system to promote the hydrolysis of cellobiose. This is due to the molecular size limitation that cellobiose is usually not able to enter the pores of zeolites (Zeolite pore sizes typically range from 0.35-2 nm, and the molecular size of glucose is approximately 0.9 nm, suggesting that the molecular size of disaccharides is close to the zeolite pore size [78,79].), and thus the addition of acid or enzymatic hydrolysis is required. Zhu et al. [73] achieved extraordinary performance by using Nb-Mont catalyst in H2O (NaCl)/MIBK = 3: 7 v: v at 170 °C for 180 min, attaining complete substrate conversion (∼100%) with significantly enhanced 5-HMF productivity reaching 68.6%. It is worth mentioning that 1Nb-Mont-500 has good recyclability and is able to maintain a stable yield over 4 cycles (∼3% drop in 5-HMF yield). In addition, Zhu et al. [73] found that the effect of temperature on the preparation of 5-HMF from cellobiose was very obvious, and the increase of temperature was favorable for the conversion of cellobiose to 5-HMF, but not the higher the better, the higher the temperature, the faster the decomposition rate of 5-HMF. Zhu et al. [73] conducted a comparative study between pure aqueous systems and saturated NaCl solutions as reaction media for 5-HMF synthesis. Their experimental results revealed that the saturated NaCl system demonstrated superior 5-HMF production efficiency relative to the pure aqueous system. This phenomenon is attributed to the salting-out effect, which promotes phase separation and reduces by-product formation through preferential solute-solvent interactions. Atanda et al. [54] and Cao et al. [53] constructed TiO2-ZrO2/Amberlyst 70 and HfO(PO4)2.0 catalytic systems, respectively, and investigated a variety of catalytic pathways for the efficient conversion of cellobiose to 5-HMF. The TiO2-ZrO2/Amberlyst 70-catalytic system, a heterogeneous composite catalyst comprising a TiO2-ZrO2 binary oxide matrix combined with Amberlyst 70 resin in an optimized 1: 1 mass ratio, demonstrates exceptional performance under the biphasic system conditions (H2O (NaCl)/THF = 1: 4 v: v). This catalytic system achieves complete substrate conversion (>99.9%) with a striking 80.8% 5-HMF yield when processing 10 wt% cellobiose feedstock maintained at 180 °C for 180 min. Cao et al. [53] synthesized hafnium phosphate catalysts (denoted as HfO(PO4)x, where x represents the P/Hf molar ratio) via co-precipitation of HfCl4 and KH2PO4. Subsequent experimental results revealed the optimal performance when the P/Hf molar ratio (x) was controlled at 2.0. This is because HfO(PO4)2.0 has an appropriate amount of strong acidic centers, whose acidity is sufficient to convert carbohydrates into 5-HMF, but insufficient to rehydrate 5-HMF into LA. The catalytic system successfully converted 10 wt% of cellobiose substrate to 5-HMF with a conversion efficiency of 98.1% under a H2O (NaCl)/THF = 1: 4 v: v, heating at 175 °C and 180 min. Summary and additions: In summary, the RP that constitute the biphasic system with cellobiose as the catalytic substrate are aqueous solutions, and the organic solvents that constitute the EP are MIBK, THF, GVL, and MeCN. Compared with monosaccharides, cellobiose has a glucose-glucose dimer structure, which requires additional pretreatment to improve conversion rates. These insights into solvent choice and catalyst design offer crucial guidance for optimizing cellobiose conversion processes. 3.2 Sucrose Mechanism of sucrose conversion: As shown in Fig. 7 b, sucrose is a disaccharide composed of glucose and fructose subunits, demonstrates distinct catalytic behavior compared to cellobiose [80]. The specific experimental case is shown in Fig. 8 b. The Nb-OH group on the surface of Nb-Mont is able to provide H+ to promote the protonation of oxygen atoms on the glycosidic bond of sucrose to produce one molecule of fructose and one molecule of glucose. The resulting fructose does not need to undergo isomerization to be dehydrated to 5-HMF. Composition of biphasic solvent systems: Table 4 have shown that the use of a biphasic system is an effective scheme for catalyzing the generation of 5-HMF from sucrose. The aqueous solution is the main component of the RP of biphasic system, and the commonly used organic solvents include MIBK, THF and GVL. Meanwhile, the inorganic salts such as NaCl and KBr play an important role in improving the 5-HMF yield. The efficiency of sucrose conversion: On the basis of optimization of conditions, many researchers have found that sucrose has higher reactivity compared to cellobiose by controlling a single variable. Atanda et al. [54] found that when sucrose is treated using the TiO2-ZrO2/Amberlyst 70 catalyst system, extremely high conversion rates (99.9%) and 5-HMF yields (85.6%) can be achieved, STY reached 0.19 × 10−6 (mol·cm−3·min−1), which was higher than that of cellobiose under the same conditions (5-HMF yield 80.8%, STY = 0.18 × 10−6 (mol·cm−3·min−1)). This enhanced reactivity can be attributed to its structural composition as a glucose-fructose dimer, which facilitates more efficient conversion pathways than those observed in cellobiose, a glucose-glucose disaccharide derived from cellulose. Significant advancement in optimizing reaction conditions and catalytic systems for sucrose conversion have been achieved by Cao et al. [44], they synthesized a series of Al-mont-n catalysts (where n represents the molar concentration of AlCl3 in aqueous solution) through an ion-exchange methodology, with Al-mont-10 exhibiting optimal catalytic activity. Under conditions of H2O (NaCl)/THF = 1: 1 v: v, 180 °C, and 150 min reaction time, the yield of 5-HMF reached 86.1% using Al-mont-10 as the catalyst. Summary and additions: In summary, sucrose, as an available reaction substrate, has efficient conversion properties due to its glucose-fructose dimer structure. In terms of organic solvent selection, MIBK, THF and GVL are better choices for EP. Some experiments used NaCl and KBr as modifiers to increase the yield of 5-HMF through salting-out effect. 3.3 Lactose and maltose Mechanism of lactose conversion: Table 5 summarizes the experimental parameters using lactose as substrates, and the conversion pathways of lactose is shown in Fig. 7 c. Lactose, a β-1,4-glycosidically linked disaccharide composed of glucose and galactose subunits, has received limited research attention in the current scientific literature, according to available documentation [81]. The conversion of lactose: In the heterogeneous catalytic system for 5-HMF production form lactose through biphasic system, water is universally employed as the primary RP, while MIBK and GVL have been extensively validated as effective EP. De et al. [82] developed TiO2-H nanocatalysts with porous nature, small particle size and strong acidity and used this catalyst in a biphasic system (H2O/MIBK = 1: 1 v: v) and reacted it for 10 min at a thermal condition of 120 °C. The productivity was still unsatisfactory and only 5-HMF yield of only 14% was obtained. The low yield can be attributed to the additional hydrolysis step during the lactose dehydration process. After few years, experimental investigations conducted by Wrigstedt et al. [29] demonstrated significant yield enhancement by implementing Ambelyst-38(wet)- CrCl3·6H2O as catalyst with KBr as the modifier. Their optimized reaction system (KBr: GVL = 1: 2) achieved substantially improved performance when operated at 160 °C for an equivalent duration, reaching an extraordinary 55% yield of 5-HMF. Mechanism/conversion of maltose: Maltose is a disaccharide consisting of two glucose units linked by an α-1,4 glycosidic bond, the conversion pathway of which is shown in Fig. 7 d. Zhu et al. [73] used 1Nb-Mont and 1Nb-Mont-500 with optimized reaction parameters (H2O (NaCl)/MIBK = 3: 7 v: v, substrate concentration of 5.04 wt%, 170 °C, 180 min), the yield of 1Nb-Mont-500 was 41.4%, while that of 1Nb-Mont catalyst was only 30.4%. This is because the Lewis/Brønsted acid sites is much lower for 1Nb-Mont (4.145) than for 1Nb-Mont-500 (7.012). Summary and additions: In conclusion, all of the above experiments indicate that lactose and maltose are disaccharides that can be exploited as substrates for the production of 5-HMF. Organic solvents that have been documented to be used as EP include MIBK and GVL, with RP remaining an aqueous solution. The summary of disaccharides: In general, disaccharides serve as structurally more complex carbohydrate derivatives than monosaccharides. The heterogeneous catalysts not only demonstrate superior catalytic activity in monosaccharide transformation processes but also exhibit significant catalytic efficacy in disaccharide conversion. As shown in the experimental results, EP consists of a variety of organic solvents, representative of MIBK, THF and GVL, while RP is more fixed on the use of aqueous solutions. 4 Catalytic synthesis of 5-HMF from polysaccharide in the biphasic system The classification of polysaccharides: Polysaccharides, characterized as high-molecular-weight carbohydrate polymers, are formed through glycosidic linkages between multiple monosaccharide units, exhibiting remarkable diversity in their structural compositions and functional manifestations [83]. In this study, polysaccharides were classified into two main groups based on their edibility: edible polysaccharides and non-edible polysaccharides [84–87]. The former category comprises nutritionally significant biopolymers, including inulin, cellulose, and starch. In contrast, the latter classification incorporates lignocellulosic biomass derivatives such as corncob, camellia oleifera shell, and wheat straw - agricultural byproducts traditionally subjected to direct combustion practices that pose significant environmental risks through particulate emissions and greenhouse gas generation. The extended carbon chain length significantly reduces the aqueous solubility of these macromolecular compounds, while the increased glycosidic bond density concurrently elevates the hydrolytic resistance of polysaccharides. These structural features place strict demands on the catalyst, necessitating careful selection of the catalytic system [4]. According to the Table 6 and Table 7 , water remains the predominant RP, while MIBK, THF, 2-BuOH, GVL, and ethyl acetate serve as EP. The results exhibited that NaCl was used as a RP modifier, while some researches employed KBr. 4.1 Edible polysaccharides 4.1.1 Inulin Mechanism of inulin conversion: Inulin, a naturally occurring fructan polysaccharide, is structurally characterized by β-2,1-glycosidic linkages predominantly connecting fructose units, typically terminated by a terminal glucose moiety [88]. As a polysaccharide widely found in nature, inulin can be catalytically converted to produce 5-HMF, and a brief reaction mechanism is shown in Fig. 9 a. Composition of biphasic solvent systems: Experimental investigations using inulin as a substrate revealed that an aqueous solution is the primary RP, augmented with various EP, including MIBK, 2-BuOH, GVL, and THF. According to Table 7, it can be seen that the amount of EP is usually greater than that of RP. MIBK emerged as a particularly effective EP component, demonstrating dual functionality in suppressing undesirable side reactions while achieving EP separation of 5-HMF from aqueous media [26]. In 1994, Moreau et al. [42] first reported the successful conversion of inulin to 5-HMF in a mixed solvent of H2O/MIBK = 1: 5 v: v in a reaction at 165 °C for 60 min using H-mordenite as a catalyst, obtaining a yield of 38.72%. The low-boiling solvent 2-BuOH is easy to separate and recover and has become a promising renewable solvent for biomass conversion [63,89]. In order to increase the yield of 5-HMF, NaCl or KBr is usually added as a modifier in the biphasic system. A biphasic solvent system (H2O (KBr)/GVL = 1: 2 v: v) was constructed by Wrigstedt et al. [29], who utilized Amberlyst-38 as a heterogeneous catalyst under microwave irradiation conditions to achieve highly efficient catalytic conversions of inulin to 5-HMF in up to 80% yield. The reason for the high yield stems, on the one hand, from the fact that the Br− promotes the dehydration step of fructose and, on the other hand, from the fact that the GVL prevents the formation of insoluble humin and the by-products LA and FA. THF is another widely used EP, which has been extensively used in catalytic biphasic systems due to its excellent extraction efficiency and the compatibility with a wide range of reaction media [44]. The conversion of inulin: Excellent catalytic results were achieved by Yang et al. [61], who used TA-p as heterogeneous catalysts in the H2O/2-BuOH biphasic system and achieved 87% yield of 5-HMF and 95% efficiency of inulin conversion after thermal treatment at 160 °C for 150 min. It is worth mentioning that inulin is a macromolecular compound, which is difficult to enter the internal pores of heterogeneous catalysts directly and needs to be treated in advance. Yang et al. [63] observed that the reaction rate of inulin without enzymatic treatment in NA-P (Niobic acid treated with phosphoric acid) heterogeneous catalysts was slow and the yield was low (yield = 54%, TOF = 15.4 mmol·g−1·h−1), and the yield of 5-HMF was significantly improved after enzymatic treatment (yield = 74%, TOF = 37.0 mmol·g−1·h−1). 4.1.2 Cellulose Mechanism of cellulose conversion: Cellulose, a linear and unbranched polysaccharide composed of β-1,4-glycosidically linked D-glucose units, is the primary structural component in plant cell walls, providing mechanical strength and rigidity to maintain cellular integrity [90]. Cellulose and hemicellulose can be derived from lignocellulosic biomass by chemical treatment, as shown in Fig. 9 b. These platform compounds (C5&C6 platform) are hydrolyzed to obtain monosaccharides, which are further dehydrated to obtain 5-HMF. Composition of biphasic solvent systems: Despite the inherent hydrophobicity of cellulose and its limited solubility in water, aqueous phase is regarded as the preferred RP for cellulose processing [91]. Commonly used EP such as MIBK, 2-BuOH, GVL and THF showed no significant difference with the solvents used for inulin, and it is worth mentioning that ethyl acetate as an environmentally friendly and innovative solvent holds significant promise for research. For example, Li et al. [92] developed a biphasic system (H2O/ethyl acetate = 2: 3 v: v) with ethyl acetate as the EP, combined with PAS-CNT (Sulfonated carbon-titanium dioxide composite nanofiber tube), and after reacting at 150 °C for 270 min, cellulose conversion yielded 12.58% 5-HMF yield. Despite the low yield (probably originating from the high energy barrier for the direct conversion of cellulose), this result validated ethyl acetate as a green and efficient organic solvent. The conversion of cellulose: As a large molecule biopolymer with limited water solubility, cellulose requires longer reaction times and higher temperatures than its structural unit, cellobiose. This phenomenon is demonstrated in the research conducted by Wrigstedt et al. [29], wherein near-identical reaction conditions were applied to both substrates. Unlike the cellulose system, the cellulose system requires an additional 15 °C increase (175 °C compared to 160 °C for cellobiose) and the product yield is significantly lower (40% compared to 71% for cellobiose). Cao et al. [53] demonstrated a significant difference in 5-HMF production efficiency between cellobiose and cellulose: the catalytic treatment of cellobiose with HfO(PO4)2.0 at 175 °C for a duration of 180 min resulted in a yield of 79.3%, while treatment of cellulose at elevated temperature (190 °C) and extended reaction time (240 min) resulted in a yield only 69.8%. Keeping the same reaction parameters (H2O (NaCl)/GVL = 1: 4 v: v, APG-SO3H (APG = Attapulgite) catalyst, 5 wt% substrate concentration, heat treatment at 160 °C for 240 min), Sun et al. [93] determined that the conversion of cellobiose was superior to that of cellulose, with 5-HMF yields of 52.4% and 35.2%, respectively. All the experimental data mentioned above show that cellulose has a weaker conversion capacity than cellobiose. However, cellulose is cheaper and more environmentally friendly to obtain, so the development of cellulosic biomass resources using biphasic systems is an effective way to address this challenge. 4.1.3 Starch Mechanism of starch conversion: Starch, a polymeric glucan composed of α-(1→4) and α-(1→6) glycosidic linkages between D-glucose monomers, is predominantly localized in the storage organs of higher plants, including endospermic seeds, tuberous roots, rhizomes, and fleshy fruits, and the brief mechanism of starch conversion to 5-HMF is shown in Fig. 9 c [77]. Composition of biphasic solvent systems: In biphasic system, aqueous solutions remain the principal RP, with phase separation facilitated by EP, specifically MIBK, THF, GVL, and ethyl acetate. Experimental data from multiple studies consistently demonstrate the most prevalent modifier is NaCl. The conversion of starch: Comparative results show that the α-glycosidic bonds in starch are more easily hydrolyzed in a biphasic system compared to the structure of cellulose, thus facilitating a more efficient conversion process. As shown in the experimental conclusions of Li et al. [92], when cellulose was used as the raw material, the 5-HMF yield was only 12.58%, and the STY was 0.065 × 10−6 mol·cm−3·min−1, which indicated that the conversion efficiency was relatively low; whereas under the same conditions, when starch was used as the raw material, the 5-HMF yield could be up to 30.43%, and the STY was 0.18 × 10−6 mol·cm−3·min−1, which showed a significant improvement. In addition to the intrinsic reaction properties of the substrates, exploring more kinds of green and efficient organic solvents is an important way to develop biphasic systems. 4.2 Non-edible polysaccharides The characteristics of non-edible polysaccharides: Non-edible polysaccharides are principally categorized into two distinct classes based on their origins. The first category comprises lignocellulosic biomass residues derived from agricultural and silvicultural activities, including corn stover, wheat straw, and pomace. These lignocellulosic biomass residues demonstrate three characteristic attributes: (1) their conventional disposal through open-field burning contributes significantly to atmospheric carbon emissions; (2) containing substantial quantities of structural carbohydrates, notably cellulose polymers, which exhibit elevated biomass energy potential; (3) it can be used as a rich feedstock for chemical synthesis due to its availability and low purchase cost. Another type of non-edible polysaccharide is extracted from microorganisms, such as microorganisms like chlorella and seaweed, which are also of great exploitation value due to their renewability and richness in carbohydrates. As shown in Fig. 10 , experiments using non-edible polysaccharides as catalytic substrates have been reported extensively, and researchers have synthesized a group of effective catalysts to produce 5-HMF in biphasic solvent system. Composition of biphasic solvent systems: Contemporary studies on the processing of non-edible polysaccharides have been documented in Table 7. The biphasic system predominantly employs aqueous solutions as the RP while utilizing organic solvent, typically MIBK and THF, as the EP. Notably, Yang et al. [94] demonstrated the application of GVL in a corn stover study, achieving a good yield of 30%, which was attributed to the significant inhibition of side reactions by GVL [95]. The conversion of agroforestry waste resources: Camellia oleifera shell, wheat straw, corncob, corn stover, and apple slurry represent lignocellulosic biomass feedstocks with substantial carbohydrate content, which have been widely used as substrates in biphasic systems. The conversion of native camellia oleifera shell biomass to 5-HMF has proven to be particularly challenging, resulting in limited process efficiency. Providentially, despite these limitations, Yang et al. [40] successfully demonstrated the fundamental catalytic capacity of FePO4 for camellia oleifera shell transformation, achieving a modest 5-HMF yield of 7.8%. The cellulose-enriched lignocellulosic biomass, characterized by its substantial abundance, demonstrates significant potential for biorefinery applications. Yang et al. [94] obtained a 30% yield of 5-HMF in an optimized biphasic system (H2O/GVL = 1: 5.4 v: v, 190 °C, 80 min) using SO3H-NG-C catalysts (NG-C = N-doped carbon support) with bis-acid sites. It is worth noting that SO3H-NG-C has a high density of sulfonic acid groups (sulphury content as high as 7.8 wt%). These sulfonic acid groups can provide protons, directly attacking the oxygen atoms of the β-1,4-glycosidic bonds in the polysaccharide chains, protonating them and weakening the bond energy, which is conducive to the hydrolysis of the polymer chains. Notably, Tempelman et al. [96] used Sn-Fn-Ac (Sulfonated carbon with the introduction of Sn) to catalyze laboratory-synthesized model hydrocarbons and real apple pomace, respectively, in a biphasic solvent system at 120 °C, H2O/MIBK = 1: 1 v: v. The model system achieved a higher 5-HMF yield (30%) compared to the 5-HMF yield of real apple pomace (24%). This is due to the presence of impurity molecules such as proteins, lignin, cellulose, pectin and polyphenols in apple pomace that competitively bind to the catalyst active site, thus deactivating the catalyst [97–99]. Therefore, catalytic conversion of agricultural biowaste may require additional pre-treatment or catalyst regeneration steps. For the biphasic system for transforming non-edible polysaccharides, water is still the most widely used RP, and the organic solvents used were MIBK, THF, and GVL, while some experiments added NaCl as a modifier to the biphasic system to promote the reaction in a positive direction. The conversion of microbial resources: After commercial extraction of β-carotene from the green microalga Dunaliella, the resulting algal biomass residue is usually discarded as waste, however, this algal residue has a carbohydrate content of up to 85.6%, making it an ideal precursor for 5-HMF synthesis [100]. Rihko-Struckmann et al. [100] utilized acidic ZSM-5 zeolites for catalysis of algal residues in a H2O (NaCl)/THF = 1: 2 v: v biphasic system, and the 5-HMF yield (30.9%) was significantly enhanced compared to the H2O/MIBK system (13.9%), as the presence of NaCl allowed the 5-HMF to be concentrated in EP. Notably, this algal residue was able to be spontaneously converted to glucose in the biphasic solvent system without purification or pre-treatment. Lima et al. [101] obtained the highest yield (60.6%) of 5-HMF by innovatively applying pre-treated Chlorella vulgaris biomass as a sustainable organic carbon source using a commercial NbOPO4 catalyst at optimal conversion parameters (H2O: MIBK = 1: 1 v: v, 210 °C, 267 min). It is worth mentioning that NbOPO4 has better catalytic performance than Nb2O5 due to higher Brønsted acid site density and lamellar structure (twofold increase in 5-HMF yield). Specifically, Brønsted acids play a leading role in the hydrolysis of polysaccharide polymer chains. The protons provided by Brønsted acids can attack the glycosidic bonds of polysaccharide chains, promoting protonation cleavage to generate oligosaccharides or monosaccharides. Lewis acid sites play a supporting role by coordinating with the carbonyl oxygen in sugar molecules, weakening the C-O bond and accelerating the hydrolysis rate. Summary and additions: In conclusion, the production of 5-HMF from polysaccharides is a challenging and innovative task that requires continuous improvement of existing catalysts, development of novel catalysts, and exploration of suitable substrates. Among the established extractants for polysaccharide conversion systems, MIBK, THF, 2-BuOH, and GVL have demonstrated particular utility in biphasic system. Notably, 2-BuOH and GVL, classified as renewable extractants, have gained significant research attention due to their enhanced sustainability profiles and demonstrated effectiveness in phase-separation systems. 5 Conclusion and perspectives This study provides a comprehensive review of research advancements in the catalytic conversion of carbohydrates to 5-HMF using heterogeneous catalysts within biphasic solvent systems. The biphasic solvent system involves a reactive phase and an extractive phase, corresponding to the solubilization of the substrate and better accommodation of the product 5-HMF, respectively, which further facilitates the synthesis of 5-HMF in heterogeneous catalysts-biphasic systems. A systematic study using a variety of substrates, including monosaccharides (glucose and fructose), disaccharides (cellobiose, sucrose, lactose and maltose) and polysaccharides (edible and non-edible categories) was carried out to analyze the effects of key process parameters on the conversion efficiency of the biphasic system and the yield of 5-HMF. In addition, the reaction mechanism of the catalytic conversion of different substrates to 5-HMF was reviewed. This systematic work provides valuable insights and basic references for advancing research on the catalytic conversion of biomass feedstocks to high-value platform compounds. Perspectives: Although significant progress has been made in the development of the biphasic catalytic system for the production of 5-HMF, some challenges still remain and need to be addressed urgently. To achieve the commercial application, further development of efficient heterogeneous solid catalysts is still required, using inexpensive waste materials as substrates, especially non-edible agricultural and forestry waste with the advancement of the green chemistry, the selection of extraction solvents should aim at achieving economic, rapid and environmentally friendly production of furan-based chemicals. coredata.dc:description: The utilization of renewable biomass as a sustainable alternative to fossil fuels has emerged as a prominent research focus in chemical engineering. This work presents a comprehensive review of recent advancements in 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) production through catalytic biomass conversion systems, with particular emphasis on biphasic solvent systems employing heterogeneous catalysts for carbohydrate transformation into 5-HMF. Systematic investigations were conducted using various substrates, including monosaccharides (fructose and glucose), disaccharides (cellobiose, sucrose, lactose, and maltose), and polysaccharides (edible and non-edible categories), with analysis of key process parameters impact on conversion efficiency and 5-HMF yield within biphasic system. Furthermore, the reaction mechanisms for the catalytic conversion of diverse substrates to 5-HMF have been comprehensively summarized. This systematic work provides valuable insights and establishes fundamental references for advancing research in the catalytic transformation of biomass-derived feedstocks into high-value platform compounds.
